head.supplied: Cambewarra ¶ 4th July 1888. ¶ ¶ […] The piece of timber (same as Log 60) I enclosed in consideration of its seasoning quicker than the logs. I had word from Baron von Muller since about this species,...

div.p: From Wilhelm Bäuerlen to Joseph Maiden
MRS 203, Inwards correspondence — special bundles, 1886-1921 Item 1, 88/unregistered, 6 July 1888, p. 75, Archives of the Powerhouse Museum, Sydney.

[…] The piece of timber (same as Log 60) I enclosed in consideration of its seasoning quicker than the logs. I had word from Baron von Muller since about this species, it does not appear to be known to him, and he seems to be inclined to consider it a Hybrid, but owing to pressure of business on account of the forthcoming Exhibition, he has at present no time to subject it to critical examination. The tradesman, who prepared my own small cabinet specimens for me, considers it excellent timber and unlike any other of the Eucapypts he had under his hands before. He also says that the timber of Eucal. macrorryncha from the Monaro, would be excellent for furniture on account of it[s] lightness and the readiness with which it takes a high polish. He did a small specimen for me lately.

Logs Nro. 63, 64, & 65 are of trees which much resemble each other, and as far as the apearance of the Bark is concerned seem to run into each other, the fruit is however quite different and also the timber, I have added no specific name to either of them, though Nro 65 is the typical Stringy Bark down here with the bright yellow fibrous bark inside. As it is worthwhile to get clear about those three species, I have put by material to send to Baron von Muller, and when I have his decision I will forward the specific names. No confusion will arise, as I keep full notes about them. […]
Not relevant.
